The surface properties of CoMg/Al2O3 were evaluated in the aerobic oxidation of p-cresol. The surface interaction is enhanced greatly after Co and Mg impregnation with the mole ratio of Co/Mg from 2 : 1 and 2 : 3. The strongest interaction for the nonpolarity and benzene ring was found on CoMg/Al2O3 with Co/Mg of 2 : 3. But for the interaction with p-π group bonding with negative anion, the highest value appears on the catalyst with the Co/Mg of 2 : 2. In aerobic oxidation of p-cresol, the conversion is significantly increased with Co addition and reaches around 60 % after 24 h' reaction at 338 K. The highest selectivity of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde of 99 % is achieved on Al2O3 with the co-impregnation mole ratio of Co/Mg of 2 : 2. It is suggested that medium adsorption of the reactants and strong stabilization of the intermediates facilitate the aerobic oxidation of p-cresol to p-hydroxybenzaldehyde. Graphic abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Surface energy Selective oxidation Cobalt Inverse gas chromatography Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction p-Hydroxybenzaldehyde (p-HBA) is an important intermediate for the production of fragrances, pharmaceuticals, pesticides, and so on [1,2]. Conventional methods including the reaction of phenols with formaldehyde [3], glyoxylic acid [4], or chloroform [5], etc., have been carried out for many years. But there are some disadvantages of high energy consumption and environmental problems of by-products. It is a clean route for the direct oxidation of p-cresol to p-HBA in promoting the overall reaction process. The oxidants of chromic acid [6], potassium permanganate [7], ozone [8], and molecular oxygen [9–13] were employed in the oxidation reaction. Among these, aerobic oxidation is a green method but a challenge due to the inertness of the oxygen gas under mild conditions. A great effort of the catalyst has been made in the catalyst design to achieve aerobic oxidation. Among the catalysts, Co species was achieved in the activation of oxygen gas and the dehydrogenation of alcohol [10,14–17]. Zhang et al. modified polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) with cobalt pyrophosphate and a high conversion of 94 % and selectivity of 94 % for p-HBA was obtained at 348 K under an oxygen pressure of 1.0 MPa [18]. The combined catalyst of cobaltous chloride and N-hydroxyphalimide (NHPI) was successfully used in oxidizing 2‑methoxy-p-cresol to vanillin by atmospheric molecular oxygen [19]. The yield of vanillin reaches around 90.1 %. The active species of Co(II) was proposed to interact with molecular oxygen to generate a labile dioxygen complex of superoxocobalt(III), which further enabled NHPI to oxidize p-cresol to p-HBA [20]. Xu et al. reported that CoMg/γ-Al2O3 exhibited excellent catalytic performance in the aerobic oxidation of p-cresol, attributing to the formation of MgCo4 compounds [21]. The interaction between the catalysts and the reactants/intermediates was determined by the property of the catalytic surface and the chemicals, influencing the aerobic oxidation p-cresol largely. Although there are some studies about the catalyst structure and composition, the mechanism of controlling the oxidation of p-cresol to aldehyde was not disclosed due to the lack of knowledge about the reactants and intermediates interaction with the catalyst surface. Inverse gas chromatography (IGC) is a useful measurement in evaluating the surface properties that are important for reactant adsorption and intermediates stabilization [22–28]. The surface interaction including polar and nonpolar components labelled with the surface energy was differentiated by the known probes. The dispersive and specific component was calculated through the adsorption of hydrophobic and hydrophilic probes, differentiating the surface interaction of the reactants, intermediates, and products. In the previous work, the surface energy was successfully used to evaluate the effect of the pore size and metal species on the reactants’ interaction, unveiling the reaction pathway [24,26]. Dispersive interaction and specific component of benzene probe successfully unveiled the CH4 dry reforming pathway on Ni/KIT-6 [24]. Recently, the adsorption behavior of the intermediates on the electrocatalysts was tuned by the surface energy, ruling the intermediates adsorption in relation with the catalytic performance in CO electroreduction [22]. The surface energy evaluated by the acid/base probes readily uncovered the adsorption behavior of the surface intermediates of *CHO, *OCH2COH, and *H on Cu/NC catalysts. In this work, the surface properties of CoMg/Al2O3 were evaluated by the probes adsorption. The interaction of the reaction functional groups with the catalyst surface was disclosed and further employed to explain the catalytic activity and selectivity in the aerobic oxidation of p-cresol. 2 Experimental methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation The metal species of Co and Mg were loaded on γ-Al2O3(Analytical reagent grade, Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co. Ltd) through wetness impregnation methods. Typically, the designed amount of the solution of Co(NO3)3 and Mg(NO3)2 (Analytical reagent grade, Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co. Ltd) was dropped on 2.0 g γ-Al2O3. Then, the sample was dried overnight, and calcined at 873 K for 2 h in the tube furnace. The weight content of Co in the catalyst is around 5 % and the mole ratio of Co : Mg is different around 2 : 1, 2 : 2, and 2 : 3. 2.2 Characterization of the materials Wide-angel X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker SMART APEX (II)-CCD with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15418 nm) at 40 kV and 30 mA. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) data were characterized by a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) measurements were performed by a JEM 2100 F (JEOL, Japan). N2 adsorption measurements were performed using a Micromeritics Tristar-3000 (Quantachrome) apparatus at 77 K. The samples were pretreated at 573 K under vacuum for 3 h before the test. The surface area was calculated by the BET method. 2.3 IGC apparatus and procedure IGC experiments were carried out on a GC6600 gas chromatography equipped with a flame ionization detector as in previous work [22–26]. Retention time was recorded on a workstation (NETChromTM, Shanghai Yingfan Ruimen Instruments Co. Ltd., China). The carrier gas (high purity nitrogen ≥ 99.999 %) was input at a flow rate of ca. 24 mL min−1. The flow rate was corrected by the James-Martin factor in the following equation (Eq. (1)). (1) V N = F j ( t R − t d ) ( p 0 − p w ) p 0 ( T T m e t e r ) where tR is the retention time (min), td is the dead time (min), p0 is the outlet column pressure, pi is the inlet pressure, pw is the vapor pressure of water at the flowmeter temperature, Tmeter , the ambient temperature, and j, the James-Martin compressibility factor defined as: (2) j = 3 2 [ ( p i / p 0 ) 2 − 1 ( p i / p 0 ) 3 − 1 ] The probes are n-hexane, n-heptane, n-octane, n-nonane, cyclohexane, trichloroethylene, tetrachloroethylene, and benzene (Analytical reagent grade, Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co. Ltd). A quartz column (20 cm long, 2 mm i.d.) was filled with the mixing solid containing the micron-sized glass beads and the catalysts (weight ratio, 5 : 1). The two ends of the column were plugged with silane-treated glass wool. Before tests, the column was stabilized on the GC system at 473.2 K overnight under a nitrogen flow. The temperature range from 423.2 to 453.2 K was chosen for the experiments. To meet the requirement of adsorption at infinite dilution, the probe volume less than 0.1 uL was injected into the column with by the automatic injector (AOC20i). Thus, the solute-solute interaction can be neglected and the retention on the catalyst surface was only related to catalyst-probe interaction. For each measurement, the dead volume td was determined by the probe of methane or n-pentane, which was employed in the retention-time tR correction for the removal of the dead volume in the column. The standard free energy is calculated by the following equation (Eq. (3)). (3) Δ G a d s = − R T ln V N p s , g π s m S where R is the gas constant, VN is the net volume of the probes, p s,g is the adsorbate vapor pressure in the gaseous standard state (101 kN m−2, 1 atm), m is the mass of the catalyst in the column, S is the specific surface area of the catalyst, and π s is the vapor pressure at equilibrium with the De Boer standard adsorption state (0.338 mN m−1) [29]. The heat of adsorption Δ H ads can be calculated from Gibbs-Helmotz equation [23,30,31]: (4) Δ H ads = − R ∂ ( ln V N ) ∂ ( 1 / T ) The dispersive component of the surface energy ( γ S D ) is due to London forces (Eq. (5)) [32]. (5) γ S D = 1 4 Δ G C H 2 2 γ C H 2 N 2 a C H 2 2 where N is the Avogadro number, a CH2 is the cross sectional area occupied by a -CH2- group (0.06 nm2), γ C H 2 (mJ m−2) is the surface tension of a surface consisting of CH2 groups, and Δ G C H 2 can be obtained from (6) Δ G C H 2 = − R T ln V N ( n ) V N ( n + 1 ) where V N ( n ) and V N ( n + 1 ) are the retention volume of n-alkanes with (n) and (n+1) carbon atoms, respectively. The specific component of the surface free energy is shown in the following equation: (7) I SP = Δ ( Δ G ) N a p where Δ(ΔG) can be determined from the difference of free energy of adsorption between a polar solute and the real or hypothetical n-alkane with the same surface area [30,32], and a p is the polar probe surface area [32]. Although this calculation is empirical, the interaction between the catalyst surface and the probes with specific functional group can be compared on a unified scale. 2.4 Aerobic oxidation of p-Cresol The aerobic oxidation of p-cresol was carried out in a three-neck glass cylindrical shaped vessel under normal pressure. Typically, 25 ml methanol and 3.6 g NaOH were placed into the reactor and mixed through magnetic stirring until NaOH was dissolved. After that, 0.35 g catalyst and 2.8 g p-cresol were added to the reactor. With stirring, the mixture was heated to 373 K, and then O2 was introduced through a fine glass disperser tube. The exit gas was passed through a reflux condenser cooled by the ice water to control the evaporation. After 24 h’ reaction, the catalyst was filtered and methanol was distilled out. The remainder was neutralized by 1 M H2SO4. Ethyl acetate was used to extract the p-cresol and products. The obtained sample was analyzed by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC, Agilent 1260) equipped with an ultraviolet detector (λmax=271 nm) on a C18 column. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Materials characterization XRD patterns of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 (a). The peaks around 2θ of 31°, 37°, 45° and 59° were observed, ascribing to MgCo4, CoO and Co3O4 species [21]. The intensity is increased with Mg addition for the formation MgCo4. However, with more Mg species impregnated, the peaks become weaker due to the coverage of Mg oxide. It was suggested that the oxide of MgCo4 was formed during the co-impregnation of Co and Mg species on nano-Al2O3. BET surface area (Table S1) was calculated through N2 adsorption. The surface area of CoMg/Al2O3 is around 110–140 m2/g. The highest surface area appears on CoMg/Al2O3 (Co : Mg = 2 : 2), indicating the surface area of samples is maintained after suitable co-impregnation of Co and Mg species. The TEM images of fresh CoMg/Al2O3 catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 (b–d) and Fig. S1. The particular morphology was not found and the aggregation of big particles is presented. With more Mg species introduction from Co : Mg = 2 : 1 to Co: Mg = 2 : 3, the particle size becomes bigger (Fig. 1 (b–d)), attributing to the formation of the large compounds of MgCo4 [21]. After calcinated at 873 K, the structure of the support is well maintained. XPS measurements were carried out to reveal the chemical states and chemical environment of the introduction species on γ-Al2O3 (Fig. 2 and Table 1). The survey spectra of CoMg/Al2O3 (Fig. 2a ) disclose the existence of Co, Mg, Al, and O, confirming that Co and Mg species were successfully loaded on γ-Al2O3. Fig. 2 (b) shows Co 2p XPS results of CoMg/Al2O3 samples. The spin-orbit split of Co 2p1/2 and Co 2p3/2 appears with the obvious shake-up satellites, due to the occurrence of Co2+ [33]. The spin-orbit coupling energies (ΔE Co 2p1/2-Co 2p3/2) are 15.7 eV and the Co 2p3/2 binding energies are around 781.4 eV for Co impregnation samples, ascribing to CoO [34,35]. It is indicated that CoO from CoAl2O4 is formed in the catalysts of Co loaded in γ-Al2O3 [36]. The Mg 1 s XPS spectra for the catalysts with different Mg loading amounts are demonstrated in Fig. 2 (c). The main peak centered at 1303.5 ± 0.3 eV was found, assigning to the formation of MgO. The intensity increases with enhancing Mg species loading. The Al 2p XPS spectra in Fig. 2 (d) exhibit that the main peak is split into three peaks of MgAl2O4, Al2O3, and CoAl2O4. After calcination, Co/Al2O3 and Mg/Al2O3 facilitate the formation of the functional groups of MgAl2O4 and CoAl2O4 [37]. With more Mg addition from Co : Mg = 2 : 1 to Co: Mg = 2 : 3, Al2O3 is transformed into MgAl2O4. The O 1 s spectra (Fig. 2 (e)) are divided into lattice oxygen (Oα, around 531.0 eV), surface defect oxygen (Oβ, around 532.0 eV), and surface oxyhydroxides (Oγ, around 532.8 eV) [38–40]. During co-impregnation of Co and Mg species, Oβ is significantly enhanced when a large amount of Mg is introduced with the ratio of Co : Mg of 2 : 3. The surface defect oxygen Oβ was considered as the active centers in the reaction, which not only enhances the interaction of reactants but also promotes the activation of O2 [41,42]. Thus, the reactive oxygen species are generated abundantly on the catalytic surface with enhanced defective oxygen centers (Table 1 ). 3.2 IGC study The effect of the flow rates on the test was investigated to remove the probe diffusion from the external surface to the bulk materials. The surface adsorption contribution can be minimized through changing the contact time between adsorbate and adsorbent [23,25]. The influence of the flow rate of carrier gas on the retention volume is shown in Fig. S2. The retention volume of the adsorbent is independent of the flowrate of the carrier gas, suggesting the limitation of the external diffusion is removed in the range from 16 mL min−1 to 32 mL min−1. Thus, the flow rate of around 24 mL min−1 was adopted in this measurement. 3.2.1 Free energy of adsorption The standard free energy of adsorption is shown in Table S2 based on the calculation using Eq. (3). The adsorption energy decreases with the temperature rising due to the van't Hoff equation. For n-alkanes, the adsorption energy increases with carbon number increment, ascribing to the enhanced sectional area. The probes with donor electron such as trichloroethylene, tetrachloroethylene, and benzene present higher adsorption energy than cyclohexane and hexane. This can be explained by the occurrence of Lewis acid sites of CoMg/Al2O3 interacting with Lewis base component of p-π [43,44]. For the chloride compounds, tetrachloroethylene with nonpolar structure presents a higher value than trichloroethylene, relating to the boiling point of the probes [26]. It is necessary for further evaluation of the specific interaction. 3.2.2 Enthalpy of adsorption Enthalpies of adsorption ΔH ads could be obtained from the slope of the plot of R lnVN versus 1/T based on Eq. (4). The results are presented in Table S3. The adsorption enthalpy of n-alkanes increases with the carbon number, ascribing to the increasing heat of condensation and physico-chemical interactions of n-alkanes [23]. Trichloroethylene, tetrachloroethylene, and benzene possess higher interaction with the catalysts than cyclohexane. Co addition enhanced the surface interaction with non-polar and polar probes higher than Mg species, unveiling the positive role for Co. In the co-impregnation, Mg species promoted the surface energy with the ratio of Co : Mg from 2 : 1 to 2 : 3. This phenomenon can be explained by the increment of the vacant oxygen sites on the catalyst surface measured by XPS. 3.2.3 Surface free energy: specific and dispersive components The dispersive component of surface energy, ΔGCH2, was determined through a plot of ΔGads versus the number of carbon atoms of n-alkanes, according to Eq. (6). With Co impregnation, the dispersive component of the surface energy is increased (Table 2 ). The medium intensity appears on CoMg/Al2O3 (Co : Mg =2 : 2), suggesting the appropriate dispersive interaction occurs on Co/Al2O3 surface with suitable Mg modification. The specific interaction on the surface, I SP, is determined between the adsorption of the polar probe and n-alkane with the same surface area (Fig. S3). The parameters, I SP, of cyclohexane, benzene, trichloroethylene, and tetrachloroethylene (Table 3 ) present the potential interaction with the specific groups of non-polarity, polarity, and benzene ring. The specific component in the surface property was enhanced largely by Co modification. For benzene, it appears a greater increment compared with cyclohexane. During co-impregnation of Co and Mg species, the specific interaction is increased with Mg addition, and a significant enhancement for the probes with benzene ring was observed. The highest value of cyclohexane and benzene appears on CoMg/Al2O3 (Co: Mg = 2: 3) due to the oxygen vacancy for metal atoms exposure and Lewis acid sites occurrence [41]. This trend was also found for the polar probes. The polar interaction evaluated by trichloroethylene is stronger than the nonpolar of tetrachloroethylene. The highest value occurs on CoMg/Al2O3 (Co : Mg = 2: 2), suggesting the potential stabilization of the intermediates with the negative group. 3.3 Aerobic oxidation of p-cresol The aerobic oxidation of p-cresol was carried out in the self-made glass reactor. Fig. 3 exhibited the catalytic performance of CoMg/Al2O3 in aerobic oxidation of p-cresol. The addition of Mg species doesn't promote aerobic oxidation, and the alcoholic product of p-methylophenol is generated largely with a selectivity of around 50 %. The Co species enhances the catalytic activity greatly in oxidation. The conversion of p-cresol reaches around 60 % when 5 % Co was impregnated. The generation of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde is significantly enhanced with the selectivity around 90 %. Small p-methylophenol and p-hydroxybenzoic acid with respective selectivity of 2 and 8 % were detected. With the co-impregnation of Mg species, the conversion changes slightly but the selectivity of the target product is tuned. The side product of p-methylophenol is reduced greatly. The excellent performance was found on CoMg/Al2O3 (Co: Mg = 2: 2) with high conversion of 76 % and the p-hydroxybenzaldehyde selectivity of 99 % at 333 K. After more Mg species was introduced, the selectivity of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde is reduced into 92 % and p-hydroxybenzoic acid is produced with the selectivity of 5 %, suggesting Mg species promotes aerobic oxidation and suitable amount of impregnation is favored in the aldehyde generation. In aerobic oxidation, the initial step of oxygen activation is carried out efficiently on Co containing catalysts [9,10,45–47]. The reactive oxygen species of the superoxide is formed [48] on the vacant oxygen sites and then oxidizes the adsorbed p-cresol. With Mg co-introduction, more oxygen vacancy species with high oxidation ability are generated. However, the interaction strength also influences the adsorption of the reactants and intermediates, relating to the contact time between the reactants and intermediates, and the catalytic surface. Strong interaction results in deep oxidation of the adsorbed chemicals by the reactive oxygen species. Medium interaction including nonpolarity and specific components results in aldehyde production by the oxidization of the alkyl group of the benzene ring, and prevents the reactants from oxidizing deeply into the carboxylic acid. In the surface interaction, the specific component was considered as the main one for the catalytic surface [23–26]. For p-cresol, the group of benzene ring plays a paramount role in the adsorption on the catalyst surface. The electron property of p-cresol-derived compounds changes with the group variation of the substituents during the oxidation process. When the surface interaction becomes strong, further oxidation will occur. But the adsorbed chemicals will desorb from the catalyst surface without further oxidation when the weak interaction happens. Thus, the product distribution is controlled by the surface adsorption energy (Scheme 1 ). The catalyst with Co : Mg = 2 : 2 exhibits the strongest stabilization for the oxide intermediates with the negative group. But for the catalyst with Co : Mg = 2 : 3, higher interaction between p-cresol and Co surface occurs, leading to the deep oxidation and generation of p-hydroxybenzoic acid. Mg species were found to enhance the surface interaction of Co catalysts through forming defective oxygen sites, influencing the oxidation process by the adsorption of the reactants and the stabilization of the intermediates on CoMg/Al2O3 surface. 4 Conclusions The surface energy of CoMg/Al2O3 was readily tuned with the co-introduction of Co and Mg species through the wetness impregnation method. IGC investigation discloses that the surface interaction is enhanced with Co impregnation and increases with the co-addition of Mg species. The aerobic oxidation of p-cresol into p-hydroxybenzaldehyde is controlled by the surface properties. High interaction of the nonpolarity and specific component for the benzene ring on CoMg/Al2O3 (Co : Mg = 2 : 3) leads to deep oxidation and p-hydroxybenzoic acid is generated. Weak surface energy on CoMg/Al2O3 results in low conversion of p-cresol. It is suggested that medium adsorption of the reactants and strong stabilization of the intermediates makes p-cresol oxidized by reactive oxygen species to form p-hydroxybenzaldehyde. Thus, IGC analysis of the surface energy gives a bright avenue to understand the surface interaction between the catalyst and the reactants. coredata.dc:description: The surface properties of CoMg/Al2O3 were evaluated in the aerobic oxidation of p-cresol. The surface interaction is enhanced greatly after Co and Mg impregnation with the mole ratio of Co/Mg from 2 : 1 and 2 : 3. The strongest interaction for the nonpolarity and benzene ring was found on CoMg/Al2O3 with Co/Mg of 2 : 3. But for the interaction with p-π group bonding with negative anion, the highest value appears on the catalyst with the Co/Mg of 2 : 2. In aerobic oxidation of p-cresol, the conversion is significantly increased with Co addition and reaches around 60 % after 24 h' reaction at 338 K. The highest selectivity of p-hydroxybenzaldehyde of 99 % is achieved on Al2O3 with the co-impregnation mole ratio of Co/Mg of 2 : 2. It is suggested that medium adsorption of the reactants and strong stabilization of the intermediates facilitate the aerobic oxidation of p-cresol to p-hydroxybenzaldehyde.
coredata.dc:title: Surface properties of CoMg/Al2O3 catalysts evaluated in aerobic oxidation of p-cresol
